summary: Charles A. Briggs was involved in handling Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) and Privacy Act requests. In 1977, he expressed appreciation for the support he received from the Privacy and Information Action Group (PIAG) and others as he transitioned out of the DDO Information Review Officer role. Later, he was involved in the CIA's JFK Records Review, where he experienced challenges due to unrealistic deadlines and inflexible standards. He was also involved in the release of JFK assassination records, specifically addressing the handling of cryptonyms, pseudonyms, file numbers, and employee names, and the extent of redactions.
significance: Charles A. Briggs' significance in the JFK context lies in his involvement in the CIA's handling of JFK assassination records, particularly concerning the release of information and the redaction of sensitive data. He was involved in the practical application of the JFK Records Act and the challenges associated with declassifying and releasing information related to the assassination.
